The Act may be cited as the "Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017" or the "LOVE Act of 2017". During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality. The Department's Bureau of Diplomatic Security forced employees out based on their sexual orientation, citing security risks. Many patriotic Americans were also barred from joining the Department due to a screening process targeting individuals who appeared to be gay or lesbian. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State faced scrutiny from Congress regarding the presence of homosexuals sympathetic to Communism and vulnerable to blackmail, leading to discriminatory hiring practices and wrongful dismissals. Government Agencies pressured the Department of State through the appropriations process due to concerns about homosexuals sympathetic to Communism. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department had to report on the number of homosexuals fired annually. The "Lavender Scare" led to discriminatory practices, with investigations into gay personnel as security risks continuing into the 1990s. In 1994, Secretary of State Warren Christopher prohibited discrimination within the Department. In the early 1990s, the Department of State investigated and removed gay personnel as security risks. In 1994, Secretary of State Warren Christopher prohibited discrimination based on sexual orientation. President Clinton signed an Executive Order in 1998 to bar discrimination. Secretary of State John Kerry apologized for past practices in 2017 and reaffirmed the Department's commitment to diversity and inclusion. On January 9, 2017, Secretary of State John Kerry apologized for the past discrimination against the LGBTI community and reaffirmed the Department's commitment to diversity and inclusion for all employees. SEC. 3. DIRECTOR GENERAL REVIEW.

The Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources of the Department of State, in consultation with the Historian of the Department of State, will review employee terminations since January 1, 1950, to identify wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation. A report compiling this information will be made public within 270 days of the enactment of this Act.

SEC. 4. REPORTS ON REVIEWS. The Secretary of State will conduct reviews to ensure consistency in the Director General's reviews under section 3. Reports on these reviews must be submitted to Congress within 270 days of the Act's enactment and annually for 2 years. Additionally, a Reconciliation Board will be established. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on the "Lavender Scare" firings. The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of inappropriate terminations and offer to change their employment records. The Secretary of State will establish a Reconciliation Board to review "Lavender Scare" firings, offer to change employment records for affected employees, designate a point of contact for testimony on discrimination, and provide a grievance opportunity for former employees not mentioned in the report. The Reconciliation Board will review claims of discrimination and termination based on sexual orientation within 150 days, with the Department of State providing necessary information to prove wrongful termination. Former employees not mentioned in the report can bring forth grievances to the Board. The Reconciliation Board will review claims of discrimination and termination based on sexual orientation within 150 days. The Department of State will provide necessary information to prove wrongful termination. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act. The Reconciliation Board will review claims of discrimination and termination based on sexual orientation within 150 days. The Department of State will provide necessary information to prove wrongful termination. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF APOLOGY. Secretary of State Kerry apologized on January 9, 2017 for past discrimination against LGBTI employees at the Department of State. He highlighted his support for the LGBTI community and efforts to promote their rights globally, including appointing a Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons in 2015. Secretary of State Kerry apologized for past discrimination against LGBTI employees at the Department of State, acknowledging historical mistreatment and expressing a commitment to diversity and inclusion. Congress also issued a formal apology for its role in the "Lavender Scare." Congress offers a formal apology for its role in the "Lavender Scare" and similar policies at the Department of State, which were influenced by congressional investigations into the "sex perversion of Federal employees." Establishment of permanent exhibit on the Lavender Scare. The Secretary of State will collaborate with the public-private partnership to create a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center. The exhibit must be installed within a year, provide access to relevant reports, and display material from oral testimonies. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE ON ISSUING VISAS.

The Secretary of State must report to Congress within 100 days on countries denying visas to Foreign Service personnel's spouses based on sexual orientation. Recommendations may include eliminating visa reciprocity with offending countries to ensure all spouses receive visas regardless of sexual orientation.

SEC. 9. ESTABLISHMENT OF ADVANCEMENT BOARD. The Secretary of State will establish an Advancement Board within the Department of State to address issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. The Board will hear testimony on discrimination faced due to sexual orientation and submit reports to Congress based on the collected testimony. The Advancement Board will annually submit a private report to Congress for 5 years based on testimony, including recommendations to prevent discrimination against State Department employees or their families due to sexual orientation. The report will only be accessible to Members of Congress, their staff, and Board members.
